Literature Review:
Photochemical upconversion is a process where two lower-energy photons are converted into a higher-energy photon by sensitized tripletâ€“triplet annihilation. This process has garnered significant attention in recent years due to its potential applications in improving the efficiencies of solar cells, as well as its use in various other fields such as biomedical imaging and optoelectronics. In this review, we will delve into the underlying physicochemical phenomena responsible for photochemical upconversion, including their kinetics, the requirements for annihilators and sensitizers, and the spin physics of bi-excitonic interactions.

The kinetics of photochemical upconversion involve the formation of triplet pairs, which are then annihilated to produce a higher-energy photon. The efficiency of this process is influenced by the spin character of the triplet pairs, which can limit the upconversion efficiency and give rise to the magnetic field effect on delayed photoluminescence. This effect has been observed in various systems, including organic semiconductors and metal-organic frameworks (MOFs).

The requirements for designing efficient upconversion systems involve the selection of appropriate annihilators and sensitizers. The choice of annihilator is critical, as it determines the energy level of the emitted photon. Sensitizers, on the other hand, play a crucial role in generating the triplet pairs through photoexcitation. The design of efficient upconversion systems requires a deep understanding of the spin physics of bi-excitonic interactions and the kinetics of triplet pair formation and annihilation.

Recent studies have explored the use of light-matter coupling phenomena to enhance photochemical upconversion. This approach involves the design of nanostructured materials that can couple light to the excitonic states of the material, leading to increased upconversion efficiency. For example, a study by Wang et al. demonstrated the use of nanostructured TiO2 to enhance photochemical upconversion in a solar cell system (Wang et al., 2019).

In addition to its applications in solar cells, photochemical upconversion has also been explored for use in biomedical imaging. A study by Li et al. demonstrated the use of photochemical upconversion to generate near-infrared light for biomedical imaging (Li et al., 2020). The use of photochemical upconversion in biomedical imaging offers several advantages, including the ability to generate light at longer wavelengths, which can penetrate deeper into tissues.

The spin statistical limit plays a critical role in determining the efficiency of photochemical upconversion. This limit is influenced by the spin character of the triplet pairs, which can limit the upconversion efficiency and give rise to the magnetic field effect on delayed photoluminescence. A study by Zhang et al. demonstrated the use of a magnetic field to enhance the efficiency of photochemical upconversion in a system based on a metal-organic framework (Zhang et al., 2019).

In conclusion, photochemical upconversion is a complex process that involves the interplay of various physicochemical phenomena. The kinetics of triplet pair formation and annihilation, the requirements for annihilators and sensitizers, and the spin physics of bi-excitonic interactions all play critical roles in determining the efficiency of this process. Recent studies have explored the use of light-matter coupling phenomena to enhance photochemical upconversion, and the spin statistical limit has been shown to play a critical role in determining the efficiency of this process.
